Be it enacted By the Senate and House of Repre-.
sentaives Of the United States Of .america in Con-
Sress assembled, That the Secretary Of the Treasu.
ry be, and he is hereby, authorized to apart and
reserve from sale. out of any Of the Public Lands
within the Territory Of Arkansas, to which the In
dian little has been, or may be, extinguishsd, and
not otherwise appropriated, quantity Of land not
exceeding two entire townships, for the use and
support OF an University within the said Territory,
and for no other use or purpose whatsoever; to be
located in tracts OF land Of not less than an eEre
section, corresponding with any Of the legal divi-
sions into which the public lands are authorized to
be surveyed, one Of which said townships, so ses
apart and reserved from SALE shall be in lieu Of an
entire township Of land directed to be locstcd on
the waters of the Arkansas river in said Territory,
Tor the use of Seminary of learning therein, by an
act OF Congress entitled " an acl making provision
for the establishment OF additional Lard offices in
the Territory of Missouri" approved February the
seventeenth, one thousand eight hundred and eigh-
teen.


Approved Cd March, 1897.

The quality of mercy is not strain'd
1t droppeth, as the gentle rain from heaven
Upon the place beneath it is twice blessd;
1t blesseth him that gives, and him that takes.
lis mightiest in the mightiest i, becomes
The throned monarch better than his crown
His sceptre shows the force of temporal power,
The attribute 10 awe and majesty,
Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings;
Qut mercy is above this scepter'd sway,
It is enthroned in the hearts o. kings,
1t is all attribute to God himself;
And earthly power doth then show likes, Gods,
When mercy seasons justice SHAKESPEARE
MERCY.

Presidents Praciamotton-The preceding column con.
tans the proclamation of the President closing ports
Of the British colonies, together with the
prohibtory acts Of 1890 and 1818 which it revives


Notwithstanding other course than this is left, do
not doubt that the factions will ring again their woted
peal of epithets and riot in the sweet sounds Of diploma
tic administration "corrupt coalition," and The other
cachwors of dscod substituted for truth and argument


But If fault lies at any door, it is at that of the opposition
who squandered away the session Of Congress in evgs
and speeches upon nothing, which would have dsgraced
nation until the very last day allotted their deliberations
has been settled plan of the opposition to the
President Of negligence, overt acts in every instance
where the public affairs have gone otherwise than smooth
yn this he has reached too farm the Georgia business
he has done enough and to the end of the
logue, with about much reason and sense the Tuks
manifest in uniformly beating the pilot when The wind be-
comes adverse.


As the matter stands, however, the public viii sanction
this measure Of Mr. Adams required BY national dgn
ty and national interests.


The opponents of the American system--those
who are hostile to the protection Of our own indus
try, and to the construction of roads and canals,
are beginning to show themselves, wherever they
exist. They hope, by identifying themselves with
the opponents of the administration, and the sup
porters of Gen. Jackson, to obtain the ascendency
IN the National Government. and crush the pro-
tecting system, which they hate. Is it not the
bl;ndest nfatuation for the farmers and mechanics
Of N. York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Kentucky, Indi-
ana. and Illinois, to unite with them?


Cincinnati Gazette, March g.

SEC. 9. .fnd be it further enacted, That the

the Treasury, not Otherwise appropriated, as COM
psnsalion 10 the several Clerks authorized by this
sci and for the additional compensation provided

Approved Cd March, 1927.

mo- s51 AN ACT to authorize the State of Indiana to


locate and make road therein named.


BE it enacted By tie Senate and House Of Repre-
sentatires Of the United States Of a,nsrica in Con
gress assembled, That the General Assembly of
The State of Indisna shall be, and the same are here
by, authorized to locate and make road from Lake
Michigan, by the way of Indianapolis, to some con-
venicnt point on the Ohio river, ngreeably to the
second article of treaty made and concluded near
the mouth Of the Mississihoway, upon the Wabash,
in the State of Indiana, the sixteenth day of Octo.
Der, In the year oi our Lord one thousand eight
hundred and twenty -four, between the Commission
srs on the part OF the United Slate' and the Chiefs
and warriors of tho Poawatamie tribe Of Indians !;
and the said General Assembly are hereby author-
zed to apply the strip of land and the sections of
land by said article csded to the United S,ates or
the proceeds thereof, to the making Of the same !;
and the said grant shall be at their sole disposal.


Approved Cd March, 1897.

mo s51 AN ACT to authorize The State of Indiana Il


locate and make a road therein named.

mo. 81. AN ACT to grant quantity Of lard 10 the


State OF Illinois, for the purpose of aiding in opening


canal to connect the waters Of the Illinois river with


those Of Lake Michigan


Be it enacted By the Senate and House of Repre-
sentatives Of the United States Of .fmerica in Con-
grsss assembled, That there be- and hereby is,
granted TO the State of Illinois, for the purpose Of
aiding the said State in opening canal to unite the
waters of the Illinois river with those Of Lake
Michigan, a quantity of land equal to one.half OF
ave sections in width, each side of said canal
and reserying each alternate section to the United
States, to be selected by the commissioner OF the
Land Office. under the direction of the President of
the United States, from one end Of the said canal TO
the other and the said lands shall be subject to the
disposal of the Legislature Of tho said State, for the
purpose aforesaid, and no other Prortded, That
the said canal, when completed, shall be- and for
ever remain, public highway for the use of the
Government of the United States, fres from any
toll, other CHARGE whatever, for any property OF
the United States, peraohs in their service, pas
sing through The ssme Provided, That said
canal shall be commenced within Ave years, and
completed in twenty years, or the State shall be
bound to pay to the United States the amount Of any
lands previously sold, and that the title to purchas-
ers under the State shall be void.


SEC Q. find be it further enacted, That, so soon
as the route of the said canal shall be located and
agreed by the said State. shall be the duty Of
the Iovelnor tneTeoi OF such otncr person OF per
sons as may have been, or shall hereafter be, au-
horized to superntend the construction Of said ca
nal examine and ascertain the particular sections
to which the said State will be entitled under the
provisions Of this act, and report the same TO the
Secretary Of the Treasury Of the United States.
SEC. 8. find be 1t further enacted That the said
S,ate under the authority Of the Legislature there
of, after the selection shall have been so made.
shall have power TO convey and sell the whole, or
any par, Of the said land, and to give title in fec
simple thereof, to whomsoever shsll purchase The
whole, or any part thereof.


| Approved Cd March, 1897.

A Deacon of country meeting, in some part u
New Hampshire, one day accosted the minister and
requested him to introduce Latin in his sermons,
making complaints because he had never done so
before. Pshaw said the Minister, you cannot un-
derstand it, and why should speak in language
which the congregation know nothing about ? Be-
cause, replied the Deacon with great sang froid we
pay for the best and want to receive the best.

himself almost into fever from his incapacity to
answer the questions, asked by one Of the Pro-
fessors-" How would you sweat patient for the
rheumatism ?"-He replied - ,Uould send him
here to be eramined.'

Oh, a Munster man. thought he was from Con-
naught," replied our Irishman, determined not to
seem totally unacquainted with the family.

fNo IS AN ACT to extend the time Of issuing and To-


eating Military Land Warrants to officers and soldiers


Of the Rev ltionary army.


Be it enacted by the Senate and House Of Repre-
sentatires Of the United States Of america in Con-
gress assembled, That the time limited by the Sc
cond section Of the act, approved the twenty fourth
day Of February, one thousaod eight hundred and
nineteen, for issuing Military Land Warrants
to the officers and soldiers OF the Revolutionary ar
my, shall be extended till the fourth day Of March,
one thousand eight hundred and thirty and the
time for locating the INDICATED warrants shall be
extended till the frs, day Of October thereafter,


Approved 81 March, 1897

teen.

full articles.headline: MERCY.
full articles.article:
The quality of mercy is not strain'd
1t droppeth, as the gentle rain from heaven
Upon the place beneath it is twice blessd;
1t blesseth him that gives, and him that takes.
lis mightiest in the mightiest i, becomes
The throned monarch better than his crown
His sceptre shows the force of temporal power,
The attribute 10 awe and majesty,
Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings;
Qut mercy is above this scepter'd sway,
It is enthroned in the hearts o. kings,
1t is all attribute to God himself;
And earthly power doth then show likes, Gods,
When mercy seasons justice SHAKESPEARE

on OF the act to fix the compensation Of the Clerks
in the different Offices passed on the twentieth OF
April eighteen hundred and eighteen, as relates 10
the clerks authorized to be employed in the office
OF the Commissioner of the General Land Office,
be repsaled and that there be employed, from and
after that period, in said ofiee, one clerk, whose
compensation shall not exceed seventeen hundred
dollars, ten Clerks, whose compensation shall not
exceed eleven hundred and fifty dollars; and six
Clerks whose compensation shall nol exceed one
thousand dollars; and that there be two hundred
and hlty dollars allowed as contingency for keep.
ing lhs account OF the three per cent. fund.- appro-
prated to the use OF certain States.


SEC. 9. .fnd be it further enacted, That the
sum Of eighteen thousand four hundred dollars be,
and hereby is, appropriated, out Of any money in
the Treasury, not Otherwise appropriated, as COM
psnsalion 10 the several Clerks authorized by this
sci and for the additional compensation provided
therein.


Approved Cd March, 1927.

INTO


effect certain Indian Treaties.


Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Repre-
ssntatires Of the United States of america in Con-
grsss assembled, That the following sums be, and
they hereby are, respectively appropriated for the
purpose Of carrying into effect Treaties made with
Chippewa, Poiawatamie, and Miami Tribe of In
dians, to wit.


The sum Of one thousand dollars, being tho sum
stipulated for by the sixth article Of the Treaty OF
The Filth Of August, one thousand eight hundred and
twenty six, with the Chippewas


The sum Of two thousand dollavs, being the anuu-
i,y to be paid to the Pottawaames, by the third ar
ticlr Of the Treaty Of the sixteenth of OCTOBER one
thousand eight hundred and twenty six.


The sum Of one thousand five hundred dollars,
for carrying into effect the same article for the
building Of a mill.


The sum Of three thousand eight hundred and
twenty dollars for carrying into effect the stipula
tion Of the same article for the support Of school
MASTER blacksmith, miller, and for the delivery
Of salt.


The sum Of thirty one thousand four hundr cd

under The fourth article Of said Treaty


The sum Of nine thousand Ave hundred and sew
enty three dollars Tor the payment Of certain claims

The sum OF hfty.seven thousand three hundred
dollars for the payment for goods delivered, and TO
be delivered, under the fourth Article OF the Trea
~ Of the ,wenty-thrd Of October. one thousand
eight hundred and twenty-six, with the Mamies.
The sum Of thirty Ave thousand dollars, for the
payment Of the annui,ies, ss provided for in the
same article Of said Treaty, the same including and
being in lieu of all former snnuities.
The sum of eight thousand seven hundred dol
lars, for carrying into effect the provisions Of the
same article, for furnishing wagons and oxen, erect
ing houses, and furnishing cattle and hogs
The sum of one thousand one hundred dollars,
for the delivery Of iron steel, and tobacco, and the
support oi aborers, provided by the same article.
The sum Of seven thousand seven hundred and
twenty dollars and forty cents. for the
payment OF certain claims, as provided for by the
fifth article fssid Treaty.
The sum of two thousand dollars, for the support
Of the poor and nHrm persons. and the education OF
youth OF the Tribe. provided for by the sixth ar
,ice Of said Treaty.


The sum Of twenty-five thousand seven hundred
dollars, as provided for by the seventh article of said
Treaty. for the purchase of certain lands, according
to the schedule therein referred to.


Sec. Q. find be it further enacted, That the same
Sc paid out of any money in the Treasury not 9th.
erwse appropriated.


| JOHN w TAYLOR,
Speaker of The House Of Representatives
NATHL. MACON.
President of the Senate, pro tempore.
! Approved: I'd March 1927
| JOHN QUINCY ADAMS.

mo s51 AN ACT to authorize The State of Indiana Il


locate and make a road therein named.
full articles.article:
mo- s51 AN ACT to authorize the State of Indiana to


locate and make road therein named.


BE it enacted By tie Senate and House Of Repre-
sentatires Of the United States Of a,nsrica in Con
gress assembled, That the General Assembly of
The State of Indisna shall be, and the same are here
by, authorized to locate and make road from Lake
Michigan, by the way of Indianapolis, to some con-
venicnt point on the Ohio river, ngreeably to the
second article of treaty made and concluded near
the mouth Of the Mississihoway, upon the Wabash,
in the State of Indiana, the sixteenth day of Octo.
Der, In the year oi our Lord one thousand eight
hundred and twenty -four, between the Commission
srs on the part OF the United Slate' and the Chiefs
and warriors of tho Poawatamie tribe Of Indians !;
and the said General Assembly are hereby author-
zed to apply the strip of land and the sections of
land by said article csded to the United S,ates or
the proceeds thereof, to the making Of the same !;
and the said grant shall be at their sole disposal.


Approved Cd March, 1897.

mo. 81. AN ACT to grant quantity Of lard 10 the


State OF Illinois, for the purpose of aiding in opening


canal to connect the waters Of the Illinois river with


those Of Lake Michigan


Be it enacted By the Senate and House of Repre-
sentatives Of the United States Of .fmerica in Con-
grsss assembled, That there be- and hereby is,
granted TO the State of Illinois, for the purpose Of
aiding the said State in opening canal to unite the
waters of the Illinois river with those Of Lake
Michigan, a quantity of land equal to one.half OF
ave sections in width, each side of said canal
and reserying each alternate section to the United
States, to be selected by the commissioner OF the
Land Office. under the direction of the President of
the United States, from one end Of the said canal TO
the other and the said lands shall be subject to the
disposal of the Legislature Of tho said State, for the
purpose aforesaid, and no other Prortded, That
the said canal, when completed, shall be- and for
ever remain, public highway for the use of the
Government of the United States, fres from any
toll, other CHARGE whatever, for any property OF
the United States, peraohs in their service, pas
sing through The ssme Provided, That said
canal shall be commenced within Ave years, and
completed in twenty years, or the State shall be
bound to pay to the United States the amount Of any
lands previously sold, and that the title to purchas-
ers under the State shall be void.


SEC Q. find be it further enacted, That, so soon
as the route of the said canal shall be located and
agreed by the said State. shall be the duty Of
the Iovelnor tneTeoi OF such otncr person OF per
sons as may have been, or shall hereafter be, au-
horized to superntend the construction Of said ca
nal examine and ascertain the particular sections
to which the said State will be entitled under the
provisions Of this act, and report the same TO the
Secretary Of the Treasury Of the United States.
SEC. 8. find be 1t further enacted That the said
S,ate under the authority Of the Legislature there
of, after the selection shall have been so made.
shall have power TO convey and sell the whole, or
any par, Of the said land, and to give title in fec
simple thereof, to whomsoever shsll purchase The
whole, or any part thereof.


| Approved Cd March, 1897.

A Deacon of country meeting, in some part u
New Hampshire, one day accosted the minister and
requested him to introduce Latin in his sermons,
making complaints because he had never done so
before. Pshaw said the Minister, you cannot un-
derstand it, and why should speak in language
which the congregation know nothing about ? Be-
cause, replied the Deacon with great sang froid we
pay for the best and want to receive the best.

fessors-" How would you sweat patient for the
rheumatism ?"-He replied - ,Uould send him
here to be eramined.'

fNo IS AN ACT to extend the time Of issuing and To-


eating Military Land Warrants to officers and soldiers


Of the Rev ltionary army.


Be it enacted by the Senate and House Of Repre-
sentatires Of the United States Of america in Con-
gress assembled, That the time limited by the Sc
cond section Of the act, approved the twenty fourth
day Of February, one thousaod eight hundred and
nineteen, for issuing Military Land Warrants
to the officers and soldiers OF the Revolutionary ar
my, shall be extended till the fourth day Of March,
one thousand eight hundred and thirty and the
time for locating the INDICATED warrants shall be
extended till the frs, day Of October thereafter,


Approved 81 March, 1897
